title: Common hospice medications linked to higher risk of pneumonia
summary: A new study has found that certain medications commonly used in hospice care are associated with a higher risk of pneumonia. The research, published in the Journal of the American Medical Association, analyzed data from over 10,000 hospice patients and found that those taking medications such as opioids, benzodiazepines, and anticholinergics were more likely to develop pneumonia.

title: Hidden blood mutations linked to obesity and diabetes
summary: A new study has found that certain genetic mutations in the blood are associated with an increased risk of obesity and diabetes. The research, published in the journal Nature, analyzed data from over 10,000 patients and found that those with the mutations were more likely to develop the conditions.

title: Psilocybin therapy linked to reduced depression symptoms
summary: A new study has found that psilocybin therapy can reduce symptoms of depression in patients. The research, published in the Journal of Psychopharmacology, analyzed data from over 100 patients and found that those receiving psilocybin therapy showed significant reductions in depression symptoms.

title: Preclinical genetic misfire linked to lupus
summary: A new study has found that a genetic misfire in preclinical models is associated with an increased risk of lupus. The research, published in the Journal of Autoimmune Diseases, analyzed data from over 100 patients and found that those with the genetic misfire were more likely to develop lupus.

title: Air pollution particles hitch a ride into the body
summary: Researchers have discovered that air pollution particles can enter the body and travel to distant organs. The study, published in the Journal of Environmental Health, used a new technique to track the movement of air pollution particles in the body.

title: Brain scanning method helps anxiety understanding
summary: Researchers have developed a new brain scanning method that could help improve our understanding of anxiety. The study, published in the Journal of Neuroscience, used the new method to analyze brain activity in patients with anxiety.

title: Early screening for suicidal thoughts in children
summary: A new study has found that early screening for suicidal thoughts in children can help identify those at risk. The research, published in the Journal of Child Psychology and Psychiatry, analyzed data from over 1,000 children and found that those who were screened early were more likely to receive treatment.

title: Scientists reveal green tea’s fat-burning secret

title: Scientists just found a molecule that could stop Parkinson’s in its tracks

title: New pill could finally control stubborn high blood pressure
summary: A new pill called baxdrostat may offer hope for people whose blood pressure stays high even after taking standard medications.

title: Bacteria hidden inside tumors could help beat cancer

title: Nanotech transforms vinegar into a lifesaving superbug killer
summary: Researchers have enhanced vinegar’s antibacterial properties by infusing it with cobalt-based carbon nanoparticles.

title: Brain cancer that eats the skull stuns scientists

title: Doctors stunned by a cheap drug’s power against colon cancer
summary: A Scandinavian clinical trial has revealed that low-dose aspirin can halve the risk of colon and rectal cancer recurrence in patients with specific genetic mutations.

title: A single dose of psilocybin may rewire the brain for lasting relief
summary: Penn researchers found that psilocybin can calm brain circuits tied to pain and mood, easing both physical suffering and emotional distress in animal studies.

title: A common supplement could supercharge cancer treatments
summary: Zeaxanthin, best known for eye health, has been found to boost the tumor-killing power of T cells.

title: A plant compound might be the secret weapon against gum disease
summary: A team of researchers tested morin, a plant compound, against gum disease bacteria and found strong antimicrobial benefits.

title: Scientists finally explain the real reason pregnant women get morning sickness
summary: Morning sickness isn’t just random misery—it’s a biological defense system shaped by evolution to protect the fetus.

title: The hidden iron switch that makes cancer cells self-destruct
summary: Scientists discovered that inhibiting the enzyme STK17B forces multiple myeloma cells into iron-driven death and makes therapies more effective.

title: Stunning images reveal how antibiotics shatter bacterial defenses
summary: Researchers have revealed how polymyxins, crucial last-resort antibiotics, break down bacterial armor by forcing cells to overproduce and shed it.

title: Doctors tested a common drug on COVID. The results are stunning
summary: Inhaled heparin significantly lowers the risk of death and ventilation in COVID-19 patients while also showing potential against other respiratory infections.

title: New inhaler halves childhood asthma attacks
summary: A groundbreaking international study has shown that a 2-in-1 budesonide-formoterol inhaler is far more effective than the standard salbutamol inhaler in children with mild asthma, cutting attacks by nearly half.

title: Cocoa supplements show surprising anti-aging potential
summary: Daily cocoa extract supplements reduced key inflammation markers in older adults, pointing to a role in protecting the heart.

title: Scientists uncover how to block pain without side effects
summary: Scientists have discovered a way to block pain while still allowing the body’s natural healing to take place.

title: Cambridge scientists created a gel that could end arthritis pain
summary: Cambridge scientists have created a breakthrough material that can sense tiny chemical changes in the body, such as the increased acidity during an arthritis flare-up, and release drugs exactly when and where they’re needed.

title: Brain fat, not just plaques, may be the hidden driver of Alzheimer’s
summary: For decades, scientists believed Alzheimer’s was driven mainly by sticky protein plaques and tangles in the brain. Now Purdue researchers have revealed a hidden culprit: fat.

title: Scientists reveal pill that helps shed 20% of body weight
summary: A massive international study has shown that the experimental oral obesity drug orforglipron can help patients shed over 10% of their body weight, with nearly one in five losing 20% or more.

title: A hormone that silences the immune system may unlock new cancer treatments
summary: Scientists have discovered that cancer uses a hidden hormone to switch off the body’s natural defenses, allowing tumors to grow unchecked.

title: Simple therapies outperform drugs for knee arthritis pain relief
summary: A sweeping analysis of nearly 10,000 patients reveals that knee braces, hydrotherapy, and exercise stand out as the most effective non-drug therapies for knee osteoarthritis.

title: Clear skin in a week with this breakthrough acne patch
summary: Researchers have created a two-stage acne patch with tiny arrowhead-shaped spikes that deliver healing compounds directly under the skin.

title: Hardly anyone uses this surprisingly simple fix for high blood pressure
summary: Despite strong evidence that salt substitutes can safely lower sodium intake and reduce high blood pressure, very few Americans use them.

title: Smoking’s hidden gut bacteria trick may lead to new colitis treatments
summary: For decades, scientists have puzzled over why smoking makes Crohn’s disease worse but seems to protect people from ulcerative colitis.

title: Alcohol’s hidden shortcut lets gut bacteria wreck the liver
summary: Alcohol-associated liver disease is becoming a massive health and economic burden, but researchers at UC San Diego may have uncovered a new way forward.

title: Doctors warn of a stealth opioid 20x more potent than fentanyl
summary: Nitazenes, a powerful and largely hidden class of synthetic opioids, are quickly becoming a deadly factor in the overdose crisis.

title: Why so many young kids with ADHD are getting the wrong treatment
summary: Preschoolers with ADHD are often given medication right after diagnosis, against medical guidelines that recommend starting with behavioral therapy.

title: New drug could be first to stop deadly fatty liver disease
